data.title: Bug: Add Cursor Above/Below
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Through the command palette, execute "Add Cursor Below" or "Add Cursor Above"
2. An error info window will show `Cannot read property 'source' of null`

More information here: https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/1652

Looks to be a regression in 1.12.1 as this does *not* repro on 1.11.2

data.title: [Feature-request] To be able to couple files together i.e angluarjs-controller <-> angularjs-template and show them side by side
data.body: Often when working in vscode on an angularjs project, the template and controller often gets separated in the tabs so I have to start looking for it. It would be nice to couple the controller and the template so that when I open the template the controller will show to the side and vice versa.

data.title: [Vue] Show correspond html close tag when click on start tag
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open .vue file (Vue js single file component: https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/single-file-components.html)
2. Click any tag start

Expected: Corresponding close tag should be highlighted.
Actual Result: All similar tags are highlighted in the current file.

data.title: Theme: "No results" in find widget is using hardcoded color

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/25836960/2ddc0eb2-348b-11e7-8b0e-38b601eac758.png)

We can then also use it in other places, e.g. preferences:

Hi,
I meet the same bug as issue #26256 ,text in terminal with wrong indentation
I'd like to add more information for that issue
- It's latest Windows 10 and VSCode.
- System in Chinese (Simplified)
- `cmd.exe` and 'powershell.exe' will meet same bug, but in` cmd.exe`, if you use `cls`, it will recover temporarily, while `powershell.exe` will not.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. press ctrl+\`
2. it occurs: text in terminal with wrong indentation. (you can see image in issue #26256)

Hope that my information can help you to fix it.
Thanks!

data.title: Change to bin/code script not using realpath.
data.body:
- some environments realpath cannot be used (by default wsl does not include it)
- Issue #13138 https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13138#issuecomment-297328734

---

Environment in error occurred

```
$ cat /etc/lsb-release
DISTRIB_ID=Ubuntu
DISTRIB_RELEASE=14.04
DISTRIB_CODENAME=trusty
DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS"

$ uname -a
Linux DESKTOP-CA3OJF3 4.4.0-43-Microsoft #1-Microsoft Wed Dec 31 14:42:53 PST 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

$ code
/mnt/c/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/bin/code: 行 7: realpath: コマンドが見つかりません
/mnt/c/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/bin/code: 行 14: ./Code.exe: そのようなファイルやディレクトリはありません
```

data.title: keyboard input + copy paste stop working sporadically
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.12.1 - OS Version: Mac OS Sierra 10.12.3 Steps to Reproduce: 1. 2. Unfortunately this is really hard to reproduce. It happens sporadically, but it has happened on 2 different computers for me (both mac OS sierra). Randomly, vscode will stop registering cmd + c or cmd + v. I've confirmed by attempting to paste the text in a different app, so it didn't even copy in the first place. IT also will not paste text copied from outside vscode. Furthermore, vscode will randomly stop accepting keyboard input. I can't type anything (and also can't copy paste while that is occurring). I can fix the second problem by restarting vscode. But often i have to restart 2 or 3 times for the first problem to be resolved. I also took a picture of my vscode `Problems` panel while this was going on, and the only errors are typescript errors: Hopefully this helps you debug the problem, and sorry i can't help you reproduce!

data.title: Update icon in explorer (or search,...) when language mode changes in editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11234139/25835053/246b5cca-347c-11e7-97db-19922f5d86df.png)

Steps to reproduce(in a more general way):

1. Install `vscode-icons` (or just use the icon set shipped with vscode) and configure to use it
2. Reload and then open a folder.
3.  Create a new file called `test.unknown`
4.  See there is no icon provided.
5. Paste in the following: `let random = Math.random();`.
6. Change the Language Mode to JS.
7.  After closing and reopen the editor the icon should be shown both in the tab and in the open editors, but not in the file explorer.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11234139/25835195/0b61df50-347d-11e7-84fd-9a37cdb481ae.png)

data.title: Update 1.12.1 Broke OTB JSDoc Creation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:26:50.689Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Right before the update to 1.12.1, in a standard .js file, I tried to generate JSDoc with "/**" + [Enter] above a function, and all of the @param elements were pre-created.
2. I updated to 1.12.1, and doing the exact same thing ("/**" + [Enter] above a function) results in just the bare JSDoc comment structure with no @param or any other elements auto-created.

BEFORE 1.12.1 Update:
/** + [Enter] did this:
```
/**
 * @param p1
 * @param p2
 */
function( p1, p2 ) { }
```

AFTER 1.12.1 Update:
/** + [Enter] does this:
```
/**
 * 
 */
function( p1, p2 ) { }
```

data.title: Suggest Widget doesnt occupy full width in split editor until a slight editor resize
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Any

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Split editors so that you have 3 editor groups and reload VS Code window
2. Start typing in any of the editor group. Observe that the suggest widget appears narrower
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16890566/25832050/098bea96-341d-11e7-9cc0-60312ba7d996.png)

3. Slightly resize any of the groups.
4. Start typing in the group that was resized. Observe that the suggest widget now occupies its full width

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16890566/25832065/1fdca768-341d-11e7-9d8b-45e7d301a4f3.png)

data.title: Cursor position not taking into account height of folded code sections when updating
Use EditorGroupinfo to decide if to swap/reposition suggest widget
data.body:
- Increased size of list, now both list and docs have same width. As mentioned in #26217 current list width is too small for many of the existing scenarios.
- Docs will not be resized. When the size is reduced too much, the type info wraps which doesnt make for a good reading.  
- Previous logic to decide about swapping/re-positioning etc restricted the suggest widget to stay inside the editor and not flow across editors. Current logic is simpler and lets the flowing of the suggest widget across editor groups.

data.title: Exclude symlinks when setting `files.watcherExclude`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.12.4

If the `files.watcherExclude` preference includes a pattern such as `**/mysymlink/**`, and the target of that symlink does not contain an actual directory named `mysymlink`, then the files will not be excluded.

This, in combination with the way the [Bazel](https://bazel.build/) build tool works, results in my org's builds occasionally failing on OSX if VSCode is open, because the OS has hits its limit on how many files can be open. In our build, Bazel created thousands of directories in its working directories, and I had tried to tell VSCode's watcher to ignore those directories, but it didn't, since they were actually symlinks, not directories.

Like I said, we use [Bazel](https://bazel.build/); Bazel creates several symlinks with names like `bazel-out`, `bazel-bin`, etc. On OSX, those map to `/private/var/tmp/_bazel_<username>/...'`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download and expand [example.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/984863/example.zip). This is a small sample project that builds with Bazel.
2. Download and install the [Bazel](https://bazel.build/) build tool.
3. Start Visual Studio Code, pointing at this directory.
4. Notice that .vscode/settings.json is configured with:

        "files.watcherExclude": {
            ...,
            "**/bazel-*/**": true
        }

    This is because, as mentioned above, Bazel will create several symlinks in the root with names that start with `bazel-*`, and will put all of the build artifacts into those directories.
5. Save a list of all file handles that VSCode's `Code Helper` program has open: `lsof | grep '^Code' > lsof-before`
6. From the command line, compile the project: `bazel build //...`
7. Now repeat step 5, saving the new list of file handles: `lsof | grep '^Code' > lsof-after`
8. Compare the two lists of files handles. You will notice that the second list of file handles is longer, and that it includes several handles for files/directories of the form `/private/var/tmp/_bazel_<username>/...`.
9. Let's fix it. Tell it to ignore those files:

        "files.watcherExclude": {
            ...,
            "**/_bazel_*/**": true
        }

10. Exit VSCode
11. `bazel clean`
12. Repeat the test.

In the above scenario, since this is a tiny sample project, you will only see a small number of newly-opened directories, so it's not a problem. But in my company's real build system, before compiling, Code Helper had 921 handles open, and after, it had 6,767, so OSX hit its handle limit and my build failed.

In general, I think I would argue that people would expect a pattern like `**/mysymlink/**` to work, and that they wouldn't want to have to think about the name of the directory that is pointed to by the symlink.
